div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders
Vol 2 - 1901
Carroll

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
NO. 226. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, October 1, 1901.

1. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Arthur S. King, 3d Battery, Field Artillery, having enlisted
under false pretences, will be discharged without honor from
the Army upon his arrival at Fort Columbus, New York, by
the commanding officer of that post. Under paragraph 1564
of the Regulations this soldier is not entitled to pay or allow-
ances, and final statements, except for deposits, shall not be
furnished him.

2. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Carlton H. Davidson, Company F, 11th Infantry, upon his
arrival at Fort Columbus, New York, will be discharged from
the Army by the commanding officer of that post, under the
provisions of paragraphs 156 and 158 of the Regulations.

3. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Stephen J. Thompson, Troop D, 8th Cavalry, Fort Sill, Okla-
homa Territory, will be discharged from the Army by the
commanding officer of his station, under the provisions of
paragraphs 156 and 158 of the Regulations.

4. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Horace W. Bullock, Company F, 14th Infantry, Fort Snelling,
Minnesota, will be discharged from the Army by the com-
manding officer of his station, under the provisions of para-
graphs 156 and 158 of the Regulations.

5. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Frank P. Tucker, Company A, 7th Infantry, Fort Davis, Alaska,
will be discharged without honor from the Army by the com-
manding officer of his station, by reason of his own miscon-
duct. This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay. He will,
however, be brought by the Government to a home port on a
transport free of charge.

6. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
William A. McAnelly, Company F, 14th Infantry, Fort Snel-
ling, Minnesota, will be discharged from the Army by the
commanding officer of his station, under the provisions of
paragraphs 156 and 158 of the Regulations.

7. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Edgar M. Patterson, Troop C, 12th Cavalry, Fort Clark,
Texas, will be discharged without honor from the Army by
3
fantry. He will be sent to the station of that company, Boise
Barracks, Idaho, and report upon arrival to the commanding
officer for duty. The expenses of the transfer will be borne
by the soldier, and transportation will not be furnished by
the Quartermaster's Department.

15. Corporal Joseph G. Wray, 69th Company, Coast Artil-
lery, Fort Monroe, Virginia, is transferred to Troop G, 11th
Cavalry, as private. He will be sent to the station of that
troop, Fort Ethan Allen, Vermont, and report upon arrival to
the commanding officer for duty. The expenses of the transfer
will be borne by the soldier, and transportation will not be
furnished by the Quartermaster's Department.

16. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the exten-
sion of leave of absence on account of sickness granted 1st
Lieutenant Marshall M. Cloud, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army,
in Special Orders, No. 48, February 27, 1901, from this office,
is still further extended three months on account of sickness.

17. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, paragraph
18, Special Orders, No. 172, July 25, 1901, from this office, is
so amended as to direct Contract Surgeon James Carroll, U. S.
Army, to return from Havana, Cuba, to his proper station in
this city not later than November 1, 1901.
✓

18. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, a medical
board to consist of--
Major William P. Kendall, surgeon;
Captain Edward L. Munson, assistant surgeon;

Contract Surgeon William C. Le Compte, U. S. Army,
is appointed to meet at the call of the senior officer thereof at
Fort Porter, Buffalo, New York, to determine the physical fit-
ness of such persons as may be ordered before it for appoint-
ment as lieutenants in the Army.

Upon the completion of his duties Contract Surgeon Le
Compte will return to his proper station. The travel enjoined
is necessary for the public service.

19. Private Christopher Hank, Company I, 14th Infantry,
Fort Porter, New York, is transferred to the 92d Company,
Coast Artillery. He will be sent to the station of that com-
pany, Presidio of San Francisco, California, and report upon
arrival to the commanding officer for duty. The expenses of
the transfer will be borne by the soldier, and transportation
will not be furnished by the Quartermaster's Department.
